text: Just out of interest but do people strategies tend to be highly correlated leading to very good days or bad days? I guess its desirable not to have highly correlated strategies to have a more level profit/roi trajectory

text: Depends on what you do. I have good and bad months, but that is just a feature of my strategies.

text: more thinking in terms of, if you have two strategies one that backs at a price and one that back the same selection if it drifts, both are profitable/ good roi, but obviously when one wins the other wins and when one looses the other loses. I was just wondering if thats typical for others (highly correlated strategies) or do they take steps to prevent / work around this

text: How would you approach the same question if you had 1 strat with high variance? Probably (depending on your risk aversity and your bank account) you wouldnt go all in on a high risk strat. If you have a solution to the problem for 1 strat, you could view your correlated strats as 1 and apply same solution. For example you can share max_runner_exposure between the two

elements.text: How would you approach the same question if you had 1 strat with high variance? Probably (depending on your risk aversity and your bank account) you wouldnt go all in on a high risk strat. If you have a solution to the problem for 1 strat, you could view your correlated strats as 1 and apply same solution. For example you can share max_runner_exposure between the two

text: I have some moderate correlation between different strategies and estimate it from pnl. But for me the first question about the strategy is always about value. If strategies are correlated and you want to reduce variance then you can adjust stakes, but in general I am happy about every strategy with value and correlation is a secondary question for me.

If strategies are correlated and you want to reduce variance then you can adjust stakes, but in general I am happy about every strategy with value and correlation is a secondary question for me.

text: they do kind a merge into one strategy, although they operate on different inputs, models, timeframes and order side as the opportunity and value all exists at the time of taking the bet. Bank structure / sizes is separate and im not really concerned about return or overly too much about risk. Several strategies may price up a market very good, i.e. backs get backed in lays get pushed out, but again this leads to a very correlated outcome across all bets. For example I may have backed something, it gets pushed it then runs awful and a horse that hasnt won in years pops up and wins. Its likely that I have layed that horse also, so you get a double hit. is this typically what others see across their bets?

text: a certain degree of correlation between postive EV strats is rather given. Oversimplifying the race quiete a bit, but: Suppose you have a Race, and some runners are overrated (negative EV if you back it), some are underrated (positive EV if you back), then positive EV strats will meet each other betting on the positve EV positions, therefore being correlated. Positive EV obviously doesnt imply postive outcome, so if one +EV strat loses, the chance for the other +EV strat to lose increases (due to increased chance of overlapping positions)

Positive EV obviously doesnt imply postive outcome, so if one +EV strat loses, the chance for the other +EV strat to lose increases (due to increased chance of overlapping positions)

text: <@ULDAVFDRP> surely this is just unavoidable if you are working off of your own calculations of each runner's probability of winning? If the market is underpricing one runner, then it has to be overpricing at least one other. If you are +EV with your model overall surely all you need to do is make sure you stake sensibly and have sufficient bankroll? I can't see how you can prevent correlation between the two if you consider laying as a different "strategy" to backing - if the market goes the wrong way and the wrong runner comes home you will clearly take a bigger hit but overall you are compensated by the races where the market goes the right way and the right runner comes home?

I can't see how you can prevent correlation between the two if you consider laying as a different "strategy" to backing - if the market goes the wrong way and the wrong runner comes home you will clearly take a bigger hit but overall you are compensated by the races where the market goes the right way and the right runner comes home?

text: Hey guys, for my background I've always just used linear regressions and made 'em work. I think it's pretty fun and you can do a lot to get around stuff, but, like I *think* <@UBS7QANF3> said a month or two ago, it's not 1904. I wanna mess with something a bit more fancy/modern, especially to handle things like non-linearity. I saw Xgboost mentioned here and am wrapping my head around decision trees a bit, they seem cool. Do you guys have other recommendations for things to look at if I'm especially interested in non-linear effects? I hear a lot about neural nets as well, not sure what the pros and cons are. Within decision trees, I'm thinking random forest models seem interesting? Just curious if there's anything else I should be thinking about if I'm looking into non-linear models.

text: Fully agree with <@UUE6E1LA1> et al, but I wanted to add something on highly correlated strategies (maybe not for you <@ULDAVFDRP> but whoever's reading) which is that there is a potential pitfall in running closely related strategies as you can exhaust market capacity without realising it. In general if you see the variance of your betting go up you should take notice of it and ask whether you might be causing it. You quite often hear things like _'just when I scaled up the variance kicked in'_ as if it can only be a coincidence, but increased variance is often the canary in the coal mine for over scaling. Say you were just backing and you added in related lays that could easily be over-scaling. It's a good idea to diversify your betting but if you're going to do it in the same markets then the best way to do it is to look for bets as far from what you're taking already as possible. That might mean laying at longer odds than you're used to or looking to bet earlier or later in the market for example. I think getting scaling wrong is probably the number one thing that holds smaller profitable players back from making really big amounts.
